name: john
note:
I am John Johnston A Primary Teacher in Scotland. I currently teach primary 4-5-6-7 in Banton Primary, the Banton Biggies.

From 1993 until 17th October 2008 a class teacher at Sandaig Primary in Glasgow.

In 20th October 2008 I joined North Lanarkshire Council as an Educational ICT Development Officer where I was until 2016.

From January 2014 till December 2015 I was on secondment to the Scottish Government to work on Glow as Product Owner mostly on Glow Blogs. I am continuing the role on a part time basis.

jdberry/tag: A command line tool to do tags on Mac files.
I donâ€™t use tags much, mainly to quickly mark a set of files going down a list with quicklook. Iâ€™ve now got an applescript that will simply tag the selection in the finder blue. Keyboard shortcut via FastScripts.

content.html: Iâ€™ve seen kingfishers on the Kelvin several times over the years, but today we watched this wee guy fishing across the river catching a few wee fish. So beautiful, thrilling.

content.html: Waxcap, perhaps?

Yesterday I was posting a note about a book and though of a slight visual joke. I needed a bit of css animation added and it seems a bit too much to either have it in the customiser or my child theme. It turns out there is a block for that: Blocks CSS: CSS Editor for Gutenberg Blocks.

This plugin just added a field to the more settings area for the block where you can add some css, Iâ€™ve used it on the image of the HyperCard icon about to animate it.

I am still not all in on using blocks, but this could be fun.
content.value:
hypercard icon 


Yesterday I was posting a note about a book and though of a slight visual joke. I needed a bit of css animation added and it seems a bit too much to either have it in the customiser or my child theme. It turns out there is a block for that: Blocks CSS: CSS Editor for Gutenberg Blocks. 



This plugin just added a field to the more settings area for the block where you can add some css, Iâ€™ve used it on the image of the HyperCard icon about to animate it.



I am still not all in on using blocks, but this could be fun.

Listened: OEG Voices 040: Charlie Farley and Lorna Campbell

content.html:
Listened: OEG Voices 040: Charlie Farley and Lorna Campbell on Two Award Winning Projects from University of Edinburgh â€“ OEG VoicesÂ a podcast produced by Open Education Global.

I huffduffed 1 this mainly to hear the voices of Alan & Lorna.

A few years ago I really hoped that the OER idea would catch on with primary & secondary teachers. Ian and I discussed this many times while working on Glow. We went to a few OER and Wikimedia events but we never got the traction to make it work.

Sharing resources for primary & secondary schools seems a very mixed bag of Facebook (I am lead to believe), the web, TES, twitter and Google Drive. The understanding of OER and creative commons amongst my colleagues is not evenly distributed yet. This is not a criticism, my knowledges of many areas I should know about is quite shaky.

I really enjoyed the listen, the work Edinburgh is doing is inspiring on all sorts of levels. I learned this included my own:

In this episodeâ€™s conversation, OER Adviser Charlie Farley shares a fabulous outreach program started in GeoSciences that has expanded to other disciplines, where students get applied open education experience working with local schools, museums, and community groups, to design and publish OERs that are shared openly through TES Resources and Open.Ed.

This has taken me to University of Edinburgh Open.Ed â€“ Teaching Resources â€“ Primary Science which looks as if it is full of a lot of useful resources for me and my school colleagues.

The ones Iâ€™ve downloaded so far are well badged with Open Education Resource and Creative Commons licenses. They also look like great resources.

I am fairly embarrassed not to have known about this, but quite excited I do now. Iâ€™d recommend a listen for inspiration & following the links for useful resources.

  1. Huffduffer is a wonderful service that allows you to gather audio from across the web into your own personal RSS feed. You can then subscribe to that in the app you listen to podcasts on. It also will rip youtube videos to audio and add them via huffduff-video â†©
